positive.review:
Excellent game so far. - lots of different playstyles to choose from and so far alot of variety too, no level is the same. No copy paste BS here. - each level is different and each one has it's own problems to complete.

Very different to what I usually play. 

It's not easy and I've struggled on some of the levels, they all have to be approached differently because it's different situations.

Hostages? - You don't know where they are, so you can't go guns blazing as you might end up getting them killed.

Mission timers? - you have to complete the mission within that time or you'll fail and/or you and the hostages die. - there's no get out of jail free card here, you're stuck on the level until you beat the timer.

Outnumbered? - You need to turn the environment into an advantage. - or use speed and surprise with flashbangs and granades.

Busting a place at night? - night vision goggles are your friend, but you have to cut the lights which are inside the place that is full of angry people with lots of guns and most likely a hostage.

Storming some shithole of a compound that has loads of corners, darkrooms, corridors, reinforced doors and windows? - you need actually think about what you're going to do.

What about suicide bombers? Jahidi's and dudes that are armed to the teeth and open fire as soon as they spot you, snipers on rooftops, booby trapped doors. Rigged explosives on cars etc. 

I'm still on the training missions and not even unlocked the good stuff yet and this game is addictive and I knew I made the right decision buying it.

I really enjoy how you have to plan EVERYTHING and executing the  perfect raid, watching it back and getting that satisfaction of all your tactics and planning coming together to beat the level... you WILL want to get three stars on every single level, because just getting one or two isn't satisfying enough. 

I highly recommend getting this game if you love tactics and planning ahead and seeing it all fold out. 

You can even pause it in real time and tweak and adjust things. 

That's my weekend sorted!

£20 is a bargain for a game this good!

Sit back, relax and enjoy this tactical master piece. Love the modding support as well for this game giving even more content than it already has! Id recommend watching yt videos if you are still on the fence or unsure if this game is for you. 
I am very pleased with my purchase. 10/10

As of hitting my 100th hour, I have yet to figure out how to play the CIA. A 4 man-squad with an emphasis on stealth and covert tactics. Requiring more thinking and planning than the fast-reliable-loud US Rangers and Nowheraki Swat.

Doorkickers 2 is a real-time strategy tactics game where you are encouraged to slow down and think your way through the map. It may not be macro-intensive, but there is still intensity to be found once the game ramps up in difficulty: bigger maps with larger squad sizes equating to more sightlines to cover, faster and more dangerous enemies, longer time investment to complete the map, timed obstacles, and more potential for failure (rocket launchers, emplacement machine gunners, elite enemies that shoot faster than your guys, and those stupid Suicide bombers).

The Replay feature makes all the trouble worth it, in my opinion. I have a lot of them stashed up, and I enjoy rewatching them from time to time, seeing all my actions unfold into one cohesive film. It's fun.

Starter Advice for New Players
If you are starting out as a new player, here are some things I learned that I will give as advice to make the early game easier and more fun:

Forgo the Medals - Medals are inherently worthless and are only there to be self-imposed challenges for players. Only take them on once you have a good grasp of the mission and have max-leveled operatives to make it easier. I stopped doing them once I got all the achievements.

Forgo Single-Planning - Same with medals. It’s not needed and should only be done once you've finished the level at least once. Don't waste your time bashing your head against a wall trying to foolproof your plan to perfection, when most single plans completely rely on RNG. To be honest, single-planning can feel very janky and frustrating to play, as the game feels better for real-time play as is inherently designed. There are no single-plan save slots, you only get only one and it is easily lost, from experience. The only exception where single plans may reliably work is for smaller and time sensitive maps(Bomb defusal and Execution), but for large maps with timed objectives above one minute, I just don't bother with it.

Do Not Be Afraid to Try All Mission Types and Sizes - While it is fun to stick to smaller-sized maps for easier quicker CQB replays, you will be missing out on the quality of one large map when you focus on the quantity of a dozen apartment or medium-sized maps. I will almost guarantee that any new player will be hesitant to try out the very large maps due to how macro-intensive it may look, having to control up to 10 units. But once you get the hang of the controls, the flow of the game, and the rhythm of slowing down to make concise decisions, large maps can be very fun and rewarding to complete.

To wrap everything up, here's a message to everyone, both veteran and new: Please give map makers the ratings they deserve. It helps boost higher-quality maps in the Steam Workshop sorting algorithm and helps the community find and play them. If you are struggling to find any good maps, I recommend going to a collection or finding those replays on YouTube. Thanks, and have fun!

Door Kickers 2 takes everything good about the first game and makes it better.  The setting is better for the type of gameplay (always being a guns blazing approach didn't really suit the police setting) and brings a massive surge of variety in terms of tools and missions.  Not only that, but having distinct types of squad is a great change to keep things fresh, with a balanced squad (Rangers), a flexible specialist squad with very limited numbers (CIA), and the quantity over quality squad (SWAT).  Different weapons and equipment varying between squads and even between troop classes inside a squad also makes a world of difference.  The scale can also get wayyyy larger than anything in door kickers 1, which is both a blessing and a curse, since managing a large map can be much harder and confusing.  That being said, all the new systems feel great and it's rare that I feel like something is brokenly overpowered or can only be done with one specific strategy.  Additionally, more control options like vaulting, sprinting, suppressive fire, crouching, and being able to tell your troopers to aim at a particular point and "slicing the pie" as they move make the original feel primitive and clunky.  All of the presentation upgrades are very welcome.  The voicelines, graphics, and sound effects make the whole game feel better.  If you feel like the game is too hard, remember your options.  Would a grenade help?  Do you need to revamp your squad's gear?  Is there a way to approach from a different angle?  Tactics can take a while to learn but is very rewarding once it clicks.

TL;DR, If you liked the original Door Kickers, then you'll love this game.  For everyone else, if you like top down tactical squad games, this is the best one on the market.

PS: Devs, please give the SWAT sapper the riot shield back like in early access.  A riot shield perfectly fits their role, and I have no clue why it was removed.

Door Kickers 2 is everything a tactical strategy fan could hope for — smarter, faster, and more dynamic than its predecessor. The game nails the feeling of planning and executing high-risk operations, giving you complete freedom to design your approach and rewarding creative thinking instead of brute force.

The improved AI, expanded arsenal, and diverse operator classes add real depth, but the controls remain intuitive enough that you can jump right in and start experimenting. Every mission feels like a fresh puzzle, and the moment your plan comes together perfectly is incredibly satisfying.

Visually it’s clean and readable, the sound design is punchy, and the pacing keeps you hooked. Whether you enjoy tight CQB planning or chaotic real-time firefights, Door Kickers 2 delivers an addictive blend of strategy and action. It’s one of the most engaging top-down tactical experiences out there — and it keeps getting better with every update.

Door Kickers 2 nails the fundamentals. The art style, engine, and overall feel are spot on, everything runs smoothly, and the tactical readability is excellent. Mods add a lot as well. I’ve had a great time playing with SAS kits, they slot right in without breaking the game. The missions are properly demanding too. You can’t just click your way through, you have to slow down, plan your angles, and think a few steps ahead.

One of the things I love is how the game pushes you to learn real CQB tactics. When you do, they actually work. Clear your corners, manage your spacing, coordinate your breach, and suddenly you’re playing on a completely different level. It’s the kind of game where you can hop in for ten minutes or sink ten hours into bigger maps and scenarios and both feel worthwhile.

My gripes are pretty small. The unlock system is the big one. Standard progression is fine, but I’m not a campaign player so having certain gear locked behind campaign completion is a bit irritating. The collision and line of sight can also get a little strange at times, though it never becomes a deal-breaker.

Even with those issues, I think it’s a fantastic tactics game. Absolutely recommend it.

Absolutely great tactical game. An improvement on DK1 in every way. Graphics look great, 3d tilt is amazing for replay mode, tough challenges, several awesome campaigns and a great random mission generator. I haven't played co-op but will soon.

My only quibbles are that (a) I wish it were possible to start a new squad with 0 stars, so they have to unlock the gear again without having to erase all of my progress on my other squads, and (b) I wish the co-op would allow you to play through an iron-man campaign (obviously you'd have to play with the same partner each time).

I'd pay money for a WW2 version of this.

My main issue with this is that it suffers from some accessibility issues because of how item descriptions are written. It seems very clear to me that item tool-tips are written more with flavor and humor attempts in mind and not at all for communicating critical information which players need to understand and approach this otherwise rather brutal gaming experience. You do have access to some sort of graph to visually communicate how for instance a weapon performs. But this is just about as vague as it gets. 

This in turn means that if you're not particularly ammo-sexual and familiar with modern weaponry, you will largely struggle to understand and grasp what items/weapons are, how they rate relative to each other, and how to improve your odds. The tool-tips read as though they're straight out of a bar-room discussions between gun nuts. How does this handgun compare versus that handgun? You won't know, but now you will have some random trivia about it under your belt. Not useful. Not helpful either.

Similarly, armors get pips. Pips to show how fast you are in them, and pips to show how much it protects the covered areas. That's it. You don't get told how much faster you will aim, move, or fire. You won't get told what suppression resistance the items afford you, nothing. You will just have a vague idea that you're about 1 pip faster and 1 pip less protected, whatever those values mean.

Difficulty wise, it's rather difficult, depending on how experienced you are with the genre. But the points explained above certainly add to the difficulty in a way that does not feel very good. There are wikis for the game, but they too do not show that missing data-oriented information. So for the most part if you play this, you will have to trudge around and try to garner a vague understanding of how weapons fare relative to each other based on your limited empirical evidence.

A bit of a missed opportunity imo.

Imagine, if you will, you’re a 31 year old ATF agent. You’ve been on the force for a while now when you get assigned to a somewhat routine mission. Some wacko has been evading his taxes as well as stocking up on illegal weaponry. You and a few of your fellow agents are advancing towards his compound through his extraordinarily long driveway when you hear it. The distinct noise of a small, propeller driven aircraft. You think *”Oh great, the bastards making a run for it”* when another noise breaks the silence among the advancing agents. You remember hearing it when you were pinned down in Afghanistan, asking for fire support towards that goddamned hill. You heard it when you rewatched combat footage from another soldiers perspective. You hoped and prayed you would never hear that noise again unless it wasnt aimed towards you. And by god, today it is. As you see your comrades getting mowed down I’m front of you, the distinctive *BRRRRRRRRRT* of a 30mm auto cannon erupts shortly after the first bullets hit their targets. The small plane then goes around for another run, miraculously leaving you in one piece, when you see something else that makes you feel even more fear than a CAS Cessna. An orange barrel, a large hazard symbol, and what looked like some sort of detonation rig. The Star Spangled Banner blares over several loudspeakers as the man youre trying to capture announces, *”TAXATION IS THEFT! DOWN WITH BIG PHARMA! ANCAPISTAN FOREVER!”*. Though it’s not what you would’ve hoped to hear, it’s the last thing you’ll ever hear.

Great idea of a game, but gets EXTREMELY repetitive and boring after the first 20 missions.

To me this game plays slow. Setting up your squad, choosing the right equipment, executing tactile gameplay; none of this has been engaging nor challenging. With enough time under my belt I feel it's not worth digging deeper to get to where I feel rewarded for my choices rather than just brute forcing every mission on hard to get 3/3 stars.  

TLDR; Too easy, just brute force everything on hard and 3 star every mission.
